query: My son with learning disabilities is turning 18 in Birmingham. How will his financial support change when he transitions to adult services?

The financial sust ainability of the social care system is a nationally recognised and widely reported 
issue , for which there has been much lobbying from the local government sector. The Government 
has set out a range of reform s, albeit the funding has yet to be confirmed fo r all aspects of change.   
The Council continues to face financial challenges and has set out a Financial Plan confirms that sets 
out the expenditure, income and savings the Council expects to face for 2022 and beyond.  Based on 
current spend and expected increases in demand it is estimated that £3 57m will be spent on adult 
social care by Birmingham City Council in 20 22/2023, which comprises 4 7% of the Council’s overall 
net budget.   
A further £ 4.3m of savings are required in 20 22/23, with a further £ 7m in 2023/24.  Many of these 
savings plans are very challenging and there are limited opportunities for alternative plans, however

The available documents don't provide specific information about how financial support for your son with learning disabilities will change when he transitions to adult services in Birmingham.

However, here are some general points about adult social care in Birmingham:

- **Adult Social Care Budget**: Birmingham City Council has allocated **£357 million** for adult social care in 2022/2023, which is 47% of the Council’s overall net budget (Document 1).
- **Financial Challenges**: The Council faces financial challenges and needs to make savings of **£4.3 million** in 2022/23 and **£7 million** in 2023/24 (Document 1).
- **Vision for Adult Social Care**: The Council aims to promote well-being and increase independence within limited resources, ensuring that people can achieve outcomes that matter to them (Document 9).

For more detailed information about the transition process and specific financial support available, you may want to contact Birmingham City Council directly or visit their website at [Birmingham City Council Social Care Services](https://www.birmingham.gov.uk/info/50173/providers_of_care_services).
